description.narrative: Complete HCFC Phase-Out in Tajikistan through Promotion of zero ODS, low GWP, Energy Efficient Technologies. To accelerate HCFC phase-out to achieve the 2020 compliance objectives and sustainably reduce the servicing tail

sector.narrative: Eradicate poverty in all its forms and dimensions

condition.narrative: Social and environmental sustainability will be enhanced through application of the UNDP Social and Environmental Standards (http://www.undp.org/ses) and related Accountability Mechanism (http://www.undp.org/secu-srm).
UNDP as the Implementing Partner will comply with the policies, procedures and practices of the United Nations Security Management System (UNSMS.)

comment.narrative:
1.1. Adopted the Resolution of the Government of the Republic “On the limitation and approval of quotas for the import of HCFCs in the period 2020-2030; Amendments to the new ENVIRONMENTAL CODE OF THE REPUBLIC OF TAJIKISTAN were prepared and submitted to the Government to the Parliament of the Republic of Tajikistan in terms of the legislative acts Law on Environmental Protection and Law on the Protection of Atmospheric Air , regarding the inclusion of three additional articles and 10 conceptual definitions for ODS and HFCs in accordance with the Montreal Protocol; In the process of preparation for submission to the Government and the Parliament of the Republic of Tajikistan, a package of legislative and regulatory legal acts for the ratification of the Kigali Amendment to the Montreal Protocol.
1.2. Due to Covid-19 the State Customs Service did not attend existing international networks on issues of ODS import & export control and other necessary bilateral and exchange visits; Procurement of 11 sets (2 tenders) analyzer-identifiers for ODS and HFCs for the Customs Service and Tajikstandart.
1.3. Standards and safety rules for natural refrigerants and HCF introduced and adapted/ applied;
A training course was conducted and 20 importers / clearing agents (including 4 women) were trained to use the introduced national system of electronic declaration of import / export of ODS and HFCs. Implementation of an electronic system (e-sealing) for tracking ODS and HFCs in transit for the Customs Service of the Republic of Tajikistan.
1.4. In close collaboration with the College of Engineering and Education and with the RAC by improving curriculum and materials to facilitate continuous training of regular and new members and other technicians on new technologies using zero ODP / low GWP refrigerants and natural refrigerants, with With a special emphasis on the safety of their use, transportation and storage, 20 training trainings (5-day) with practical exercises in the main regions of the country were held. 432 technicians were trained, including: 72 people in 2019; in 2020 255 people. and in the first half of 2021, 105 people. Eight (8) technicians and experts participated in 5 ECA network meetings and a conference on energy efficient technologies with zero ODP and low GWP online (due to the pandemic).
2.1. Procurement of 12-15 sets of equipment and tools for technicians and service of RAC companies (maintenance of refrigeration and air conditioning equipment to eliminate refrigerant leaks).
2.2. Procurement and supply of 10 sets of medium-temperature refrigeration equipment and refrigeration rooms (chambers) of medium size for catering units of large medical institutions (Ministry of Health and Social Protection of the Republic of Tajikistan) and other social facilities using new technologies with zero ODP and low GWP .
3.1 and 3.2. To implement activities on raising public awareness, the project continued previous efforts in this area, and relevant information materials and booklets, related to the ozone layer and Montreal Protocol, the introduction of natural refrigerants, are published on the UNDP platforms (e.g. UNDP Facebook), websites of the partners of the project (e.g. Committee of Environmental Protection under the Government of the Republic of Tajikistan, Customs Service of the Republic of Tajikistan, RAC Association, etc.). TV programs and round table discussions mainstreamed and conducted with the support of the Gender Outreach Specialist and partner coordinators of the project. In specific reference to annual celebrations of the World Environment Day (June each year) and Ozone Day (September each year), the project team along with the government and UNDP Country Office is arranging special dedicated events related to competitions and contests. The project is also organizing the information tour for 10 – 12 journalists within the country to highlight achievements of the project to continue activities on increasing public awareness, and to develop and publish information materials. The project plans to conduct this activity in 30 July – 30 October 2021
4.1. the Engineering-Pedagogical College of Dushanbe under the Ministry of Labor, Migration and Employment of the Population of the Republic of Tajikistan have established two classes/groups on RAC for girls and young women students consisting of 30 students (10 female) who will graduate by end March 2021. 5 graduated women students are offered to work in the Engineering-Pedagogical College of Dushanbe under the Ministry of Labor, Migration and Employment of the Population of the Republic of Tajikistan.
4.2. regular monitoring and evaluation of the project activities and projects results conducted and presented to PSC members in PSC meeting in July 2021; Project Implementation Report was developed and submitted to UNDP-GEF in July 2021;

1.1. At least 1 regulatory legal document on stepwise HFC phase-out developed and presented to the Government; Experience exchange carried-out through (two) study visits in regional conferences and other countries with advanced experience in the region; 1.2. The State Customs Service attended existing international networks on issues of ODS import & export control and other necessary bilateral and exchange visits; The laboratory of the Customs Service, the Environmental Protection Inspectorate, Tajikstandart equipped with new equipment for the identification of HCFCs and HFCs. An electronic cargo tracking system is in place, while the number of cases of illegal trade in ODS has been minimized. 1.3. Cooperation enhanced with RAC Association, and promoted long-term education of new members of Association and other technical specialists with new technologies using refrigerants with zero-ODP and low-GWP, including natural refrigerants; Ensured participation of 2-3 technical staff in network meetings and international workshops related to new technologies with zero-ODP and low-GWP, and energy efficiency (EE), which initially discussed and agreed with technical staff.
2.1 Demonstrated innovative projects for piloting of energy-efficiency technologies with zero-ODP and low-GWP. 2.2 Equipping 2–3 RAC training centers with 4-5 sets of training stands and equipment.
3.1 Continued provision of public awareness raising activities and campaigns. Information materials and activities developed for the HCFC phase-out process, available in Russian and Tajik languages, reaching over 5,000 people. 3.2 Conducted at least 2 (two) public awareness raising activities.
4.1 5-6 women receive scholarships for study and education in the RAC sector. In addition, 10–12 women will be encouraged to participate in RAC-related small businesses in private companies. 4.2 Presented results of conducted monitoring and evaluation of the project at the meetings of the Project Steering Committee. 4.3 Expanded cooperation with the Committee on Environmental Protection (COEP) under the Government of the Republic of Tajikistan to conduct country assessments and collect data on HCFCs and HFCs, for reporting to the Ozone Secretariat. 4.4 Conducted Final and Terminal Evaluation (TE) of the Project.
